title: 107_s1563
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Agricultural Bioterrorism Countermeasures Act of 2001". Congress finds that the events of September 11, 2001, have raised concerns about bioterrorism threats, including attacks on the food supply and agriculture. Evidence suggests terrorists may be interested in using biological or chemical weapons, posing risks to human health, public confidence in food safety, and the economy. Strategies and technology are needed to address these challenges effectively. The Act aims to enhance research and development capabilities to combat agricultural bioterrorism, foster collaboration between different sectors, and strengthen regulatory agencies. The Act aims to enhance research and development capabilities to combat agricultural bioterrorism and strengthen regulatory agencies to prepare for and respond to bioterrorist attacks. The term "Secretary" in this Act refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. The Act also focuses on intramural agricultural bioterrorism research and development. The Secretary of Agriculture is required to expand Agricultural Research Service programs to protect the food supply by enhancing response capabilities, collaborating with partners, strengthening linkages with the intelligence community, engaging with international organizations, and taking appropriate measures. $140,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2007 for this purpose. SEC. 5. CONSORTIUM FOR COUNTERMEASURES AGAINST AGRICULTURAL BIOTERRORISM. The Secretary will establish a Consortium for Countermeasures Against Agricultural Bioterrorism, comprised of institutions of higher education focused on research and development to enhance biosecurity in US agriculture. Membership includes 3 national centers and up to 7 additional institutions with programs related to agricultural bioterrorism. The Secretary will establish a Consortium for Countermeasures Against Agricultural Bioterrorism, comprised of institutions of higher education focused on research and development to enhance biosecurity in US agriculture. The national centers selected must meet specific criteria related to expertise in plant and animal diseases, linkages with diagnostic laboratories, and coordination with extension programs. $50,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2007 for this purpose. SEC. 6. The Secretary will award grants for research on protecting against bioterrorism in agriculture. $30,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2007.

SEC. 7. The Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service activities will be expanded. The Secretary will enhance the capacity of the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service by increasing inspection capacity at international points of origin, improving surveillance at ports of entry, and adopting new strategies and technology to protect against plant and animal disease organisms introduced by terrorists. The measures include enhancing preparedness of Veterinary Services, strengthening coordination with State and local agencies, and taking other appropriate actions. Authorization of Appropriations: $140,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually for fiscal years 2003 through 2007 to carry out the measures outlined in the previous paragraph. SEC. 8. EXPANSION OF FOOD SAFETY INSPECTION SERVICE ACTIVITIES. The Secretary will enhance Food Safety Inspection Service capacity by improving meat and poultry product inspections, developing rapid disease detection methods, applying new technologies for inspection procedures, inspecting international products, and promoting collaboration among agencies. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of $140,000,000 for technology in fiscal years 2003 through 2007.
